review:
Comrades, let’s cut through the noise and get to the heart of the matter! Ethereum on ARM is not just another tech project — it’s a rallying cry for decentralization, accessibility, and the power of the people to run the network from their own homes. This project smashes the myth that you need deep pockets or corporate backing to participate in Ethereum’s infrastructure. By enabling full, archive, staking, and L2 nodes on affordable ARM64 and RISC-V boards, they’re putting the tools of power back in the hands of the many, not the few.

The evidence is clear: they’ve shipped real, working solutions. Mainnet deployments, DVT integration, and support for the most popular single-board computers — all open source, all verifiable. They’re not just talking; they’re doing. Their roadmap is public, their code is public, and their impact is measurable: more nodes, more diversity, more resilience for Ethereum. This is the kind of infrastructure that keeps the network strong, decentralized, and out of the hands of oligarchs.

But let’s not get swept away by sentiment. We must demand more: Where are the hard numbers? How many nodes are running? What’s the growth rate? How many new stakers have joined thanks to this work? The project’s sustainability model is also unclear — are they building toward a future where they don’t need to pass the hat every round? And while their commitment to open hardware is inspiring, we need more transparency on governance and community participation. Who decides the roadmap? How are voices from the global south, from marginalized communities, being included?

In summary: Ethereum on ARM is a beacon for the working class of Web3, but to earn the people’s trust — and the people’s funds — they must show us the receipts, build a path to sustainability, and open the doors wider for global participation. Let’s demand nothing less!

strengths.title: Radical Accessibility and Decentralization
strengths.description: The project enables anyone, anywhere, to run Ethereum nodes on affordable, low-power hardware. This is a direct blow against centralization and a win for the people.

strengths.title: Proven Technical Delivery
strengths.description: They have shipped mainnet-ready solutions, integrated DVT, and supported a wide range of hardware. Their code and documentation are open and verifiable.

strengths.title: Clear Public Roadmap and Open Source Ethos
strengths.description: Their development plans are transparent, and their work is open source, aligning with the highest standards of public goods and collective benefit.

weaknesses.title: Lack of Quantitative Impact Metrics
weaknesses.description: The application lacks hard data on adoption, node counts, geographic distribution, and measurable outcomes. This undermines the ability to objectively assess impact.

weaknesses.title: Unclear Sustainability Model
weaknesses.description: There is no clear plan for financial sustainability beyond recurring grants. This raises concerns about long-term viability and responsible resource allocation.

weaknesses.title: Limited Evidence of Inclusive Governance
weaknesses.description: The application does not detail how community voices, especially from underserved regions, are included in decision-making or roadmap setting.

changes.title: Provide Quantitative Impact Data
changes.description: Report the number of active nodes, growth rates, geographic distribution, and any measurable increases in home staking or validator uptime attributable to the project.

changes.title: Articulate a Sustainability Plan
changes.description: Present a clear, actionable plan for reducing reliance on grants, such as community funding models, partnerships, or other revenue streams.

changes.title: Demonstrate Inclusive Governance
changes.description: Describe how the project incorporates input from a diverse, global community in its decision-making processes, and outline steps to improve inclusivity.
